articles.headline: Xbox Takes On Cable, Streaming TV Shows and Movies
articles.snippet: If talks with Disney work out, the game console could stream ESPN content, making it that much easier to watch TV without cable.
articles.abstract: If talks with Disney work out, the game console could stream ESPN content, making it that much easier to watch TV without cable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at Microsoft are fond of saying that its subscription gaming service, Xbox Live, should be thought of as a cable channel.

articles.headline: Glassmaking Thrives Offshore, but Is Declining in U.S.
articles.snippet: American glassmaking, like so many other manufacturing industries before it, is moving abroad. To protect the remaining glassworkers’ jobs, some are seeking tariffs on imported glass.
articles.abstract: American glassmaking, like so many other manufacturing industries before it, is moving abroad. To protect the remaining glassworkers’ jobs, some are seeking tariffs on imported glass.
articles.lead_paragraph: The majestic steel beams of a soaring office tower beginning to rise from the ruins of the World Trade Center are a tribute to American resilience, but also a marker in the decline of yet another industry. Not an inch of imported glass went into the two lost towers, built 40 years ago. The lower floors of the new one will soon be sheathed in Chinese glass.

articles.headline: Swiss Banker Blows Whistle on Tax Evasion
articles.snippet: A former Swiss banker called offshore tax evasion “the biggest theft among societies and neighbor states.”
articles.abstract: A former Swiss banker called offshore tax evasion “the biggest theft among societies and neighbor states.”
articles.lead_paragraph: From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy.

articles.headline: As Haitians Flee, the Dead Go Uncounted
articles.snippet: Along with everything else stolen by last week’s earthquake, Haitians must now add another loss: the ability to identify and properly honor the dead.
articles.abstract: Along with everything else stolen by last week’s earthquake, Haitians must now add another loss: the ability to identify and properly honor the dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: TITANYEN, Haiti — A few miles north of the busted-down buildings in Port-au-Prince, up a hillside where cows graze, an empty hole awaits the dead. Rectangular, 20 feet deep and wide, 100 feet long, it is one of the newest mass graves, but there are many more.

articles.headline: Kraft Is Said to Reach Deal for Cadbury
articles.snippet: Kraft tentatively agreed to pay about $19 billion in cash and stock for the confectioner, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.
articles.abstract: Kraft tentatively agreed to pay about $19 billion in cash and stock for the confectioner, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kraft Foods has reached a tentative deal for a friendly takeover of Cadbury of Britain, agreeing in principle to pay about $19 billion in cash and stock for the confectioner, people briefed on the matter said on Monday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Deluge of Donations via Text Messages
articles.snippet: As of late Sunday, the American Red Cross had collected pledges of $103 million, about $22 million of which came through a text-messaging program.
articles.abstract: As of late Sunday, the American Red Cross had collected pledges of $103 million, about $22 million of which came through a text-messaging program.
articles.lead_paragraph: A push by celebrities, athletes and the first lady encouraging text-message donations for earthquake relief in Haiti has contributed to a fund-raising bonanza for the American Red Cross, which a little over a year ago turned to Congress for a bailout.

articles.headline: Big, in Banks, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
articles.snippet: There is still little agreement between lawmakers and bankers on how to limit the risks created by huge financial institutions.
articles.abstract: There is still little agreement between lawmakers and bankers on how to limit the risks created by huge financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Can a bank be too big?

articles.headline: Pandit Is Running Out of Time to Clean Up Citigroup
articles.snippet: After billions of dollars in losses at Citigroup, Vikram S. Pandit must make a profit in 2010, or risk losing his job as chief executive.
articles.abstract: After billions of dollars in losses at Citigroup, Vikram S. Pandit must make a profit in 2010, or risk losing his job as chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is make or break time for Vikram S. Pandit.

articles.headline: U.S. Troops Patrol Haiti, Filling a Void
articles.snippet: Haiti’s long history of foreign invasion has made an influx of foreigners a delicate issue.
articles.abstract: Haiti’s long history of foreign invasion has made an influx of foreigners a delicate issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  American military helicopters landed on Tuesday at Haiti’s wrecked National Palace, and troops began rolling through the capital’s battered streets, signs of the growing international relief operation here. But the troops’ presence underscored the rising complaints that the Haitian government had all but disappeared in the week since a huge earthquake struck.
